newsitem.title: UK: Britain confirms death of U.N. worker in Rwanda.
newsitem.headline: Britain confirms death of U.N. worker in Rwanda.

text.p: The British government confirmed on Tuesday that a Briton was one of four United Nations employees who were killed in an ambush in Rwanda.
"We are deeply shocked by this incident and all our sympathy goes to the families of the victims and their co-workers," a spokesman for the Foreign Office told Reuters.
"We are in close touch with the U.N. authorities in Kigali and in New York. We are seeking more information on the incident and we understand the U.N. will issue a press statement shortly," he added.

U.N. human rights spokeswoman in Kigali, Marie Vander Elst, said earlier on Tuesday that the four were conducting their normal duties as part of a human rights monitoring team in the commune of Karengera approximately 350 km (200 miles) southwest of Kigali on the Zairean border when they were attacked.
The bodies of the victims were due to be flown to Kigali on Tuesday night. No other details were available.
It was the latest in a series of attacks on foreigners in Rwanda. Six foreigners have died in the escalting violence, including a Canadian priest who was killed by an unidentified gunman on Sunday.
A Rwandan official suggested hardline hardline Hutus who fled Rwanda after committing genocide against minority Tutsis in 1994 could be involved.
